Non-conventional fuels. Transportation and handling.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1T), RCS Focused, FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1T ((3-1T)), RCS - FCS (Focused)

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Electrochemical principle of corrosion reactions. Corrosion thermodynamics and kinetics. Electrochemical corrosion measurement techniques. Passivity and pitting corrosion. Crevice corrosion and galvanic corrosion. Environmentally assisted cracking. Corrosion control techniques including cathodic protection, coatings and inhibitors. Material selection for corrosion resistance.

Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year standing or above.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Petroleum Engineering 563 and Mechanical Engineering 519.18 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1T), FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1T ((3-1T))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Description and analysis of heavy oil geology and heavy oil recovery technologies. Discussion of heavy oil production mechanisms and methods, recovery process design, transportation, facilities, marketing, economics, and environmental issues.

Prerequisite(s): Petroleum Engineering 429 or 523.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Petroleum Engineering 573 and 519.01 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1T), FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1T ((3-1T))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Long Course Title: Tight Oil and Unconventional Gas Exploitation
Description:
Overview of tight oil and unconventional gas resources (tight gas, shale gas, tight oil, shale oil, coal bed methane, and natural gas hydrates) in a 'Total Petroleum System'. Geological aspects, drilling, completion and stimulation methods; reservoir characterization by petrophysics and well test analysis; forecasting methods; environmental and regulatory issues; economics and cost drivers.

Prerequisite(s): Petroleum Engineering 429 or 523.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Petroleum Engineering 573 and 519.02 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1T), FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1T ((3-1T))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Overview of heavy oil, tight oil, and unconventional gas resources (tight gas, shale gas, tight oil, shale oil, coal bed methane, and natural gas hydrates) in a 'Total Petroleum System'. Geological aspects, drilling, completion and stimulation methods; reservoir characterization by petrophysics and well test analysis; forecasting methods; discussion of production mechanisms and methods, recovery process design, transportation, facilities, marketing, economics, environmental and regulatory issues.

Prerequisite(s): Petroleum Engineering 429 or 523.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1), FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Basic reservoir engineering principles including fluid flow in porous media, rock and fluid properties; estimation of recovery under different operating conditions.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B, Fee Rate Group(International) -D, GFC Hours (3-1), FRGD - B (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B), FRGI - D (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - D), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Analysis of fluid flow from the formation to the surface including inflow performance, wellbore hydraulics, multiphase flows and well stimulation techniques.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B, Fee Rate Group(International) -D, GFC Hours (3-1), FRGD - B (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B), FRGI - D (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - D), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Data analysis and integration for reservoir modeling and simulation.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B, Fee Rate Group(International) -D, GFC Hours (3-1), FRGD - B (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B), FRGI - D (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - D), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Introduction to water and polymer flooding, miscible displacements and surfactant flooding with focus on case studies.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B, Fee Rate Group(International) -D, GFC Hours (3-1), FRGD - B (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B), FRGI - D (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - D), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Basic principles of natural gas production and processing including properties of natural gases, vapour-liquid equilibrium and separation techniques.

Notes:  This course does not count towards the degree requirements of MSc and PhD students.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B, Fee Rate Group(International) -D, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - B (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B), FRGI - D (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - D), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Basic principles of analyzing the profitability and risk of energy projects including project selection, investment ranking, budgeting and portfolio development.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Petroleum Engineering 626 and Chemical Engineering 687 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B, Fee Rate Group(International) -D, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - B (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B), FRGI - D (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - D), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ENPE - Petroleum Engineering
Description:
Overview of modern drilling technologies and techniques including drilling hydraulics, directional drilling, drilling fluid properties and selection, well control and completion methods.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Petroleum Engineering 627 and either Chemical Engineering 689 or Chemical Engineering 619.91 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B, Fee Rate Group(International) -D, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - B (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - B), FRGI - D (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - D), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ENPH - Engineering Physics
Long Course Title: Research and Design for Engineering Physics I
Description:
Introduction to engineering design and testing; project management; teamwork; scientific inquiry; research skills and methods; identifying market and societal needs; innovating scientific techniques to analyze problems, and developing relevant technologies; intellectual property and regulatory issues; ethics in research and design, including documentation and treatment of data. Case studies as necessary.

Prerequisite(s): Admission to the BSc in Engineering Physics.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-3/2), FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-3/2 ((3-3/2))

Subject: ENPH - Engineering Physics
Long Course Title: Fundamentals of Circuits and Systems I
Description:
Characterization of circuit devices and systems in the time-domain. Natural, step, and transient responses of RL, RC, and RLC circuits. Semiconductor theory and device modelling, including diodes and operational amplifiers. Continuous-time and discrete-time analysis of systems. Impulse response and convolution.

Prerequisite(s): Physics 259 and Engineering 225; and Mathematics 375 or 376.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-3), RCS Related, FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-3 ((3-3)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: ENPH - Engineering Physics
Long Course Title: Research and Design for Engineering Physics II
Description:
A team-based design and research project carried out under the supervision of one or more faculty members, with a focus on design. The project can include designing experimental apparatus, developing technical devices, performing laboratory measurements, simulating systems or developing software, and building theoretical and physical models. Students will be required to submit a written report and deliver an oral presentation.

Prerequisite(s): Engineering Physics 301.
Course Attributes: ET Focused, Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (1-4), RCS Focused, ET - FCS (Focused), FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 1-4 ((1-4)), RCS - FCS (Focused)

Subject: ENPH - Engineering Physics
Long Course Title: Fundamentals of Circuits and Systems II
Description:
Characterization of circuit devices and systems in the frequency-domain. Laplace transform methods for circuit analysis. Transfer functions and series and parallel resonance. Basic filter theory and Bode diagrams. Two-port circuits. Digital sampling theory and frequency-domain signal processing. Rectifier and clamping circuits, and introduction to transistors.

Prerequisite(s): Engineering Physics 388.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Engineering Physics 488 and either of Electrical Engineering 327 or 343 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-3), RCS Related, FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-3 ((3-3)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: ENPH - Engineering Physics
Description:
Modelling, analysis, and design of dynamic systems involving multiple physical processes, including structural, electrical, fluidic, thermal, and mixed systems; introduction to and utilization of numerical techniques for solution of boundary-value problems; introduction to feedback control of dynamic systems; performance analysis and design to meet specifications.

Prerequisite(s): Physics Engineering 383 and 435, Physics 449, Electrical Engineering 475, and Engineering Physics 488.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Engineering Physics 491 and Mechanical Engineering 461 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1T-3/2), RCS Focused, FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1T-3/2 ((3-1T-3/2)), RCS - FCS (Focused)

Subject: Energy Resources Engineering
Description: Comprehensive overview of various energy pathways and their role in the global energy transition, including geothermal energy harvesting, compressed air energy storage, hydrogen storage, and CO2 sequestration. Invited industry experts. Emphasis on systems thinking, sustainability, stakeholder engagement including Indigenous perspectives on resource development, achieving net zero emissions, and interaction of technology and society.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-2), RCS Related, FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-2 ((3-2)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: Energy Resources Engineering
Description:
Principles and practices of air pollution control, with focus on process design for carbon-based energy sources. Methods for detecting emissions. Application of fundamental engineering principles to design and optimize processes that mitigate air pollution from the mining, exploration, production, transportation, and utilization of coal, oil, and natural gas. Design of unit operations, separation processes, treatment technologies, and carbon capture methods to control emissions of methane, volatile organic compounds, carbon dioxide, particulate matter, sulfur oxides, and nitrogen oxides. 

Prerequisite(s): Chemical Engineering 405.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1), FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1))

Subject: Energy Resources Engineering
Long Course Title: Data Science and AI in Energy Systems
Description:
Applications of data science, machine learning, artificial intelligence and optimization in energy systems. Review of statistics, probability and data science concepts; confidence factors and error analysis. Supervised and unsupervised learning in python including regression and clustering; data engineering for data filtering and feature selection; optimization. Focus on application to problems in the energy industry. 

Prerequisite(s): Digital Engineering 319 and Chemical Engineering 307.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1), RCS Related, FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: Energy Resources Engineering
Long Course Title: Digital Energy Field and Cyber Security
Description:
Introduction to Digital Energy Systems; Data acquisition and digital transformation; Role of IoT (Internet of Things) in energy management; Fundamentals of cyber security; Identifying and assessing cyber risks in energy systems; Strategies for risk mitigation and management.

Prerequisite(s): Digital Engineering 319.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1), FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1))

Subject: Energy Resources Engineering
Description:
Overview of hydrogen as an energy carrier. Hydrogen Production Methods: Electrolysis, Steam Methane Reforming, Biomass Gasification, etc.; Hydrogen Storage methods: compressed gas storage, Liquid Hydrogen Storage, Solid-state Storage, Underground Storage. Hydrogen chemistry, reactivity, and safety. Economic and Environmental Considerations. 

Prerequisite(s): Third-year or higher standing.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1), RCS Related, FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: Energy Resources Engineering
Description:
Current technologies in energy extraction from subsurface resources. Geoenergy vs. geothermal energy, power generation vs. heat distribution, open vs. closed loop systems, properties of working fluids (surface vs. subsurface) deep drilling and fracturing, applications at urban vs. remote communities, regulatory issues with geothermal energy, description of new technologies. 

Prerequisite(s): Third-year or higher standing.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1), FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1))

Subject: Energy Resources Engineering
Description:
Carbon dioxide emissions reduction, geological storage mechanisms, saline aquifers, depleted oil and gas fields, mineral trapping, reservoir characterization, site selection, injection techniques, rates and efficiencies of geological storage, monitoring and verification, risk assessment, regulatory frameworks, cost analysis, environmental impacts, and public perception, geological carbon sequestration technologies and their role in mitigating climate change.

Prerequisite(s): Third-year or higher standing.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1), RCS Related, FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: Energy Resources Engineering
Description:
Critical minerals and applications, sources, production capacities, supply chains, and disruption risks, extraction technologies for critical minerals and their environmental impact, emerging sustainable extraction technologies, recycling, circular economy. Extractive metallurgy, hydrometallurgy, separation technology, supply chain disruption, sustainable mineral extraction technologies.

Prerequisite(s): Third-year or higher standing.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D, Fee Rate Group(International) -C, GFC Hours (3-1), RCS Related, FRGD - D (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - D), FRGI - C (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - C), GFCH - 3-1 ((3-1)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: ENSC - Environmental Science
Description: Topical issues in environmental science including climate change, aquatic systems, agriculture, forestry, mining, energy, endangered species, and protected areas contextualized within the framework of law, policy, economics, sustainability, and the precautionary principle.
Course Attributes: ET Focused, Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), No Prerequisite, RCS Focused, ET - FCS (Focused), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0)), NREQ - NREQ (No Prerequisite), RCS - FCS (Focused)

Subject: ENSC - Environmental Science
Description:
An introduction to the common field techniques in quantifying air, land and water quality, as well as data analysis and report writing. A field portion is held in the two weeks prior to the start of the regular Fall Term, partly based at the Biogeoscience Institute's Barrier Lake Field Station.

Prerequisite(s): Biology 315 or Statistics 327; and admission to the Environmental Science program.

Notes: This course occurs in rugged field conditions and varying weather, for which participants must be prepared and equipped. A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course. Students will require consent of the program to drop this course.

Description:
The focus will be on disturbances to aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. Site visits and data collection will be conducted to appropriate areas that have either undergone or are undergoing industrial disturbance to assess impacts. The course is held for two weeks immediately prior to the start of the regular Fall Term.

Prerequisite(s): Environmental Science 401 and admission to the Environmental Science program.

Notes: This course occurs in rugged field conditions and varying weather, for which participants must be prepared and equipped. A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course. Students will require consent of the program to drop this course.

Introduction to professional skills practices within software engineering. Individual software processes and reflection, resiliency and debugging skills, command line navigation, revision control. Foundations of database management systems. Types of data models, relational and entity-relationship models, integrity constraints, normalization, Structured Query Language (SQL). Data privacy, security, and ethical considerations.

Description:
Explores formal principles of software engineering based on the common recognition that software engineering is not constrained by any physical laws as we know. The transdisciplinary foundations of software engineering are presented from the facets of information, computing, mathematics, cognitive, and management sciences, software engineering philosophies; engineering, mathematical, computational, management science, cognitive informatics, computational intelligence foundations and approaches of software engineering. As a result, a coherent framework of software engineering theories is learnt.

Prerequisite(s): Admission to the PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering or the MSc in Electrical Engineering.

Description:

Different types of neural networks; how to train and deploy them in various problems; Fine-tuning pre-trained models to achieve state-of-the-art results in relevant applications; overview of the current trends in deep learning.

Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering.

Antirequisite(s):  Credit for Software Engineering for Engineers 617 and Electrical Engineering 619.51, 645 or 682 will not be allowed.

An introductory course in programming with an emphasis on data engineering. Topics include: basic data structures and algorithms; loops and iterations; files and I/O, functions, classes, modules, and packages; strings and text manipulation; data wrangling; network and web programming; data visualization.

Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering.

Description:
A fundamental study of software design and development topics for engineering students. Topics include: fundamental programming constructs; key features of an object-oriented programming language, especially inheritance and polymorphism, elements of object-oriented design; programming and application of common data structures; strategies and tools for testing and debugging.

Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Software Engineering for Engineers 693 and either 519.49 (Principles of Software Dev I) or 593 will not be allowed.

Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MEng with specialization in Software Engineering.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Software Engineering for Engineers 694 and either 519.50 (Principles of Software Dev II) or 594 will not be allowed.

Description:
Introduction to the various business disciplines from the perspective of creating a new business venture. The primary learning methodology is a term project; students identify a business opportunity, research the opportunity, and write a business plan for the business.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Entrepreneurship and Innovation 201 and either Management Studies 217 or Strategy and Global Management 217 will not be allowed.

Notes: Not available for credit towards the Bachelor of Commerce. Required for the minor in Management and Society and the minor in Entrepreneurship and Enterprise Development.

Description:
Course will address the "wicked problem" of designing your life and career journey. Students will develop frameworks, tools, and a sense of community through engagement with the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

NOT INCLUDED IN GPA

Subject: ENTI - Entrepreneurship and Innovation
Description:
Leaders in today's business environment are challenged to think entrepreneurially-to seek opportunities and find ways to turn opportunities into viable for-profit business ventures, social ventures or not-for-profit organizations. They are challenged to do more than just business; giving back to society is expected. The primary learning methodology is through a project in which an opportunity is identified, researched, and the results of a feasibility assessment are written and presented.

Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Haskayne School of Business Bachelor of Commerce program, Management Studies 217 and Strategy and Global Management 217.

Subject: ENTI - Entrepreneurship and Innovation
Description:
The dynamics of innovation as the primary driving force within firms and modern industrialized economies. Potential concepts are: incremental versus radical innovations, market-pull versus technology-push theories, dominant designs, technological trajectories, key factors for successful innovation. The emergence of new technologies; the importance of national and regional innovation systems; the role of science, regulations and social pressure in innovations dynamics; knowledge management; and implications for firms in rapidly changing industrial settings may be discussed.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 793)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - F, Fee Rate Group(International) -E, GFC Hours (3-0), RCS Related, FRGD - F (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - F), FRGI - E (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - E), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: ENTI - Entrepreneurship and Innovation
Description:
The process of taking a technology product or service from development to the market, including market strategies, finding investors and potential early customers, the role of advisors, legal issues and the importance of the exit strategy for founders and early stage investors. Students will be required to complete a major project to write a feasibility study for a new technology or a case study of a successful technology venture.

Also known as: (formerly Entrepreneurship and Innovation 791)

With the changing political landscape, social enterprises blur the traditionally separate roles of governments, non-governmental organizations, for-profit companies, and charities. Concentration will be on for-profit models, but many of the principles and tools will be applicable to any entrepreneurial or intrapreneurial (new social or environmental change initiatives in existing organizations) endeavours with a social mission.

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Basic concepts regarding the major features of Earth; its rock and mineral composition, processes controlling erosion, deposition and surface structures; formation of mountains, ocean basins and continents; internal structure of the Earth and plate tectonics. 

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 209 and Geology 201 will not be allowed. 

Also known as: (formerly Geology 209)

Notes: Not open for credit to Honours, Majors or Minors in Geology, Geology (Petroleum Geology Concentration), Applied and Environmental Geology, Geophysics, Environmental Science (Geoscience Concentration) or Natural Sciences (Geoscience Concentration).

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Our home planet is the only place we know of that is inhabited by living things. What makes Earth unique? By identifying rocks and minerals and interpreting evidence collected from geologic maps and models, students will uncover the materials that make up the Earth, their origin, age, distribution, and processes that recycle them over time including those operating below, at, and above Earth's surface. Students will also explore resource and environmental management.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 210 and any of Geology 201, 202, or 376 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: ET Related, Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-3), RCS Related, ET - RLT (Related), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-3 ((3-3)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Description:
Focus on designing and performing field-based investigations; logistics of planning and running field activities; and field safety. Topics will include navigation, sampling, and field reports across a variety of topics within Earth, energy, and environmental sciences. 
  
NOT INCLUDED IN GPA.

Notes: This course is primarily lecture-based with field trips, which may occur in rugged conditions and varying weather, for which participants must be prepared and equipped. A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course. The course will typically be offered in Spring and/or Summer terms over a period of up to three weeks.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (80-120 Hours), No Prerequisite, ET Related, RCS Focused, ET - RLT (Related), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - (80-120HR) ((80-120 Hours)), NREQ - NREQ (No Prerequisite), RCS - FCS (Focused)

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Lectures and study in Earth sciences.

Notes: This course is not part of the Field of Geology or the Field of Geophysics.

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Long Course Title: Geology of the Mountain Regions of Western Canada
Description:
Selected topics encountered in introductory physical geology will be pursued in greater depth to explain the geology of Western Canadian Mountain Parks and adjacent areas. 

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 209, 210, Geology 201 or 209.

Also known as: (formerly Geology 301)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Biology, evolution, and extinction of dinosaurs; geographic and temporal distribution, habitats, and ecology of the various dinosaur groups; preservation, exploration, collection, preparation, and identification of dinosaur fossils. 

Also known as: (formerly Geology 305)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (2-1T), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 2-1T ((2-1T))

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
The history of life from the earliest records to the present. Fossils, geological time, extinction, basic paleontology. The rise and development of various animals and plants including dinosaurs, mammals and humans. 

Also known as: (formerly Geology 307)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
An overview of human health issues related to geological phenomena. Examples of possible topics include medical geology, heavy metals in groundwater, effects of volcanic eruptions, effects of asbestos-type minerals, acid mine drainage and soil nutrient deficiencies. 

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 209, 210, Geology 201 or 209.
 
Also known as: (formerly Geology 308)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Field-based study of Earth oriented toward non-majors. Study and interpretation of geological and/or geophysical information in the field, and its significance to social and environmental issues. Field studies will normally be conducted away from Calgary in the spring or summer semester (destinations vary). 

Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

Notes: This course occurs in rugged field conditions and varying weather, for which participants must be prepared and equipped. It may occur outside Canada. A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course. Students will require consent of the department to drop this course. Not open for credit to Honours, Majors or Minors in Geology, Geology (Petroleum Geology Concentration), Applied and Environmental Geology, Geophysics, Environmental Science (Geoscience Concentration) or Natural Sciences (Geoscience Concentration).

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT
Course Attributes: ET Related, Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (80-100 Hours), RCS Related, ET - RLT (Related), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 80-100 HRS ((80-100 Hours)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Systematic description and classification of minerals, rocks, and ores. Characterization of minerals using macroscopic and microscopic properties, especially structure and chemical composition. Use of textures and mineralogy to understand first-order conditions of formation of common sedimentary, igneous, metamorphic, and ore-related rocks. 

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; and Chemistry 201 or 211; and Chemistry 203 or 213.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 310 and either Geology 313 or 423 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-3 ((3-3))

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Earth surface and near-surface processes and the variety of environments they create and modify at a range of spatial and temporal scales. Investigation of systems and conditions that control the weathering, transport, and deposition of Earth materials, with emphasis on applications to the sedimentary rock cycle and soil formation.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; Physics 211 or 221; and Chemistry 203 or 213.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 320 and Geology 381 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-3 ((3-3))

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Processes controlling water movement and storage above, on, and beneath Earth's surface. Collection, analysis, and interpretation of hydrological, geophysical, and water quality data at a variety of spatial and temporal scales. Examination of impacts of natural and human activities on water resources, including issues related to water quality, availability, and sustainability.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; and Chemistry 203 or 213; and Physics 211 or 221; and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265, or 275.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 330 and Geology 353 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-3 ((3-3))

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Processes and mechanisms of rock deformation at plate tectonic to microscopic scales and a range of temporal scales (seconds to millions of years). Description of deformation features and analysis of the forces that cause them.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; and Mathematics 211 or 213; and Physics 211 or 221.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 340 and Geology 445 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-3), RCS Related, FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-3 ((3-3)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Earth's climate system and life, and the geologic record of how they have changed through time. Investigation of the geologic data used to reconstruct past intervals of climate and biological upheaval with comparison to modern rates of change.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 350 and either of Geology 475 or 493 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-3 ((3-3))

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Application of physical principles to understanding Earth and other bodies in the Solar System. Examination of evidence for Earth formation and structure considering thermodynamics, gravity, seismology, and magnetism. Analysis of Earth's lithosphere including plate motion, earthquakes, and comparison of oceanic and continental crust.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 210, Geology 201 or 202; and 3 units from Chemistry 201, 203, 211 or     213; and Physics 211 or 221; and Mathematics 249 or 265; and 3 units from Computer Science 217, 231, 235 or Data Science 211.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Earth 360 and Geophysics 351 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-3), RCS Related, FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-3 ((3-3)), RCS - RLT (Related)

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Long Course Title: Natural Disasters and Critical Earth Phenomena
Description:
Causes of disasters such as earthquakes, tsunami, volcanic eruptions, mud flows, landslides, avalanches, flooding, tornadoes and hurricanes, and other critical phenomena such as sinkholes, ozone depletion and radiation, carbon dioxide and global warming, El Nio, toxic natural materials and pollution, and extraterrestrial impacts. Surveys of historic disasters and their effects on life on Earth. Methods of prediction and prevention of disasters and precautions for the mitigation of their effects. 

Notes: This course is not part of the Field of Geology or the Field of Geophysics.

Also known as: (formerly Geophysics 375)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
The development of field-based techniques in the collection, description, analysis, interpretation, and reporting of geoscientific field data and results. Includes navigation, geological mapping, field sampling, and geophysical methods. Multiple days of field work outside of the classroom in methods related to each of geology, hydrogeology, and geophysics. 
  
Prerequisite(s): Earth 210 and 290. 

Notes: This course takes place off-campus for ~12-14 days and may occur in rugged conditions and varying weather, for which participants must be prepared and equipped. A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course. The course will typically be offered in Spring and/or Summer terms.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (80-120 Hours), ET Related, RCS Focused, ET - RLT (Related), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - (80-120HR) ((80-120 Hours)), RCS - FCS (Focused)

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Exploration of various areas in Earth. Topics will vary from year-to-year. It will be offered as required to provide the opportunity for students to engage in additional areas in Earth. Before registration, consult the Department of Earth for topics offered. 

Prerequisite(s): Consent of the Department.

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
A written report based on independent study. Originality is emphasized, laboratory and field studies are encouraged.

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
A written report based on extensive independent study. Originality is emphasized, laboratory and field studies are encouraged.

Also known as: (formerly Geology 510)

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Field-based study of complex geoscience topics. Advanced skills development in one or more aspects of field data collection, portrayal, description, analysis, and interpretation. Field work will normally be conducted away from Calgary in the spring or summer semester (destinations vary).

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Earth 390 or Geology 337 and consent of the Department.

Notes: This course occurs in rugged field conditions and varying weather, for which participants must be prepared and equipped. It may occur outside Canada. A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course. Students will require consent of the department to drop this course.

Subject: ERTH - Earth, Energy and Environment
Description:
Courses are offered in contemporary topics in areas such as electrical and electromagnetic methods, exploration and environmental geophysics, geochemistry, gravity and magnetics, hydrogeology, integrated geophysical methods, mineralogy, paleontology, petroleum geology, petrology, quantitative geology, sedimentology, seismology, structural geology, and surficial geology. 
 
Prerequisite(s): 78 units and consent of the Department.

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Long Course Title: Energy Use in the Modern World
Description:
Overview of how the world's energy systems work and why these energy systems are essential to how society functions. Examination of benefits and drawbacks of the sources of energy people use; generation and distribution of electricity; energy efficiency; and environmental consequences of energy choices

Prerequisite(s):  Chemistry 30 or Chemistry 212.

Antirequisite(s): Physics 371.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), ET Related, ET - RLT (Related), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Introduction to the thermodynamics of how heat engines transform heat into useful forms of energy for electricity and transportation. Examination of using pV diagrams to calculate work; efficiency; waste heat; and changes in entropy.

Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201 or admission to Natural Science (Energy Science Concentration); and 3 units from Physics 211, 221, 227; and 3 units from Physics 223, 259, or 355.

Antirequisite(s) Credit for Energy Science 317 and Science 507.17 (Engines and Electricity) will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Science 317)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-2T), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-2T ((3-2T))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Long Course Title: Climate Change Causes, Adaptations, and Mitigations
Description:
Principles of climate change and the interplay between anthropogenic climate change and energy systems.  Earth's current changing climate; the effects of greenhouse gases and human activity; the impact of climate change on society and the environment; and climate change mitigation and adaptation.

Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201; 3 units from Physics 211, 221, 227; and 3 units from Physics 223, 259, or 355.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Discussion of a particular topic on energy science at the 3XX level. The topic will be determined by the course instructor and will be communicated to students before the start of term.

Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201 and admission to Energy Science Major or Minor.

MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-1T or 3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-1T/3-0 ((3-1T) or (3-0))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Overview of nuclear energy production, including the nuclear fuel cycle, the workings of atomic nuclei, nuclear reactions, nuclear cross-section, reactor design, uranium mining, waste disposal, and both beneficial and harmful biological effects of radiation.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317, Physics 449, or Chemistry 371; or Engineering Energy and Environment 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Also known as: (formerly Science 421)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-2T), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-2T ((3-2T))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Scientific principles behind batteries and fuel cells, including the electrochemistry of classic voltaic and electrolytic cells; thermodynamics, kinetics, and performance curves of batteries and fuel cells; and current applications and limitations.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317, Physics 449, or Chemistry 371; or Engineering Energy and Environment 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Also known as: (formerly Science 423).
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-2), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-2 ((3-2))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
The science behind capturing and using solar energy for human utilization, covering sunlight energy conversion; solar photovoltaic systems; integration of solar power into energy systems; and environmental, societal, and economic issues related to solar project development.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317, Physics 449, or Chemistry 371; or Engineering Energy and Environment 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Also known as: (formerly Science 427)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-2T), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-2T ((3-2T))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Introduction to the fundamentals of utilizing energy from water in the environment.   Examination of hydrology and fluid dynamics; electricity generation from rivers, ocean waves, tides, and ocean currents; pumped storage; and environmental, societal, and economic issues.

Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201; or Energy Science 317 and admission to Natural Science (Energy Science Concentration); and 3 units from Physics 211, 221, or 227; and 3 units from Physics 223, 259, or 355; or Engineering Energy and Environment 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Antirequisite: Credit for Energy Science 431 and Science 531 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Science 431)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-2), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-2 ((3-2))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Overview of utilizing thermal energy from the ground, including low and high temperature geothermal systems; ground-source heat pumps; geothermal heating; and related technical, environmental, and socioeconomic issues.

Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201; or Energy Science 317 and admission to Natural Science (Energy Science Concentration); and 3 units from Physics 211, 221, or 227; and 3 units from Physics 223, 259, or 355; or Energy and Environment, Engineering 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Energy Science 433 and Science 533 will not be allowed.

Also known as: (formerly Science 433)
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-2), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-2 ((3-2))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Overview of the energy from biomass, including  the production of biomass feedstocks; the conversion of biomass to energy or to feedstocks for other products; the use of biomass in transportation, electricity, and heat generation; its societal impacts such as air pollution; and economic and technical limitations.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317, Physics 449, or Chemistry 371; or Energy and Environment, Engineering 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Overview of fossil fuel energy and hydrocarbon systems.  Examining the history and geography of development of fossil fuel resources; upstream, midstream, and downstream components; conventional oil and gas, heavy oil and shale gas/oil resources; liquified natural gas (LNG); abatement of greenhouse gas emissions using carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS); and Indigenous perspectives on Canadian fossil fuel development and extraction.

Prerequisite(s):  Energy Science 317 and 321.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Overview of wind energy including generating electricity from wind, including turbine types and relevant fluid dynamics; limitations to wind power such as the Betz limit and variable supply; environmental consequences related to wind energy; interactions between wind power producers, the electricity system, and the environment.

Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 201; or Energy Science 317 and admission to Natural Science (Energy Science Concentration); and Physics 211, 221, or 227; and Physics 223, 255, or 355; or Energy and Environment, Engineering 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-0 ((3-0))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Overview of minerals that are critical to energy science, including economic importance and supply risk; decarbonizing energy systems and the digital economy; the exploration, production, processing, and distribution of critical minerals; and socioeconomic, Indigenous, and environmental perspectives.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Energy Science 317 or Geology 323; or Energy and Environment, Engineering 355 and admission to the Schulich School of Engineering.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (3-2), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 3-2 ((3-2))

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Discussion of a particular topic on energy science at the 4XX level. The topic will be determined by the course instructor and will be communicated to students before the start of term.

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Overview of the role of energy policy in energy systems including the history of energy policy, the policy making progress, principles of policy analysis and policy communication, and the impact of energy policy on energy systems. The course will cover different aspects of energy policy at the international, national, and subnational level including climate/emissions policy, environmental assessment and review current issues in energy policy.

Prerequisite(s): Energy Science 321; and 6 units of courses labeled Energy Science (ESCI) at the 400-level or above.

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Team-based course where students integrate the knowledge and skills from previous courses to critically evaluate local, national, and/or global energy-system scenarios to sustainably deliver the energy society needs into the future.

Prerequisite(s): Economics 201; and 3 units from Indigenous Studies 303, 343, or 345; and Energy Science 321; and 12 units of courses labelled Energy Science at the 400 level or above.

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science

An independent study course for students to research a topic related to energy working closely with a faculty member.  

Prerequisite(s): 15 units in the Field of Energy Science and consent of the Faculty.

Subject: ESCI - Energy Science
Description:
Research project under the co/supervision of faculty members in the Department of Biological Sciences. Original and independent thought, practical research, and written and oral reports presented on completion of this course. 

Prerequisite(s): 15 units of Energy Science and consent of the Faculty.

Discussion of a particular topic on energy science. The topic will be determined by the course instructor and will be communicated to students before the start of term.

Prerequisite(s): 15 units of courses labelled Energy Science (ESCI) and admission to Energy Science Major or Minor.

Notes: This course is part of the Field of Energy Science.

Subject: FILM - Film
Description: An introduction to thefoundationalissuesandvocabularyof film studies explored through a wide range of filmic texts. Privileging questions offilmtechnique and style, the course also considers cinemaas an institution that comprises an industrial system of production, social and aesthetic norms and codesandparticular modes of reception.

Subject: FILM - Film
Long Course Title: Introduction to Research in Film Studies
Description:
An in-depth introduction to conducting research in film studies, emphasizing critical viewing, reading and writing through the examination of a specific topic, such as a film genre, a national cinema, or a filmmaker.

Corequisite(s): Prerequisite or Corequisite: Film 201.

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
Topics will explore various aspects of, or historical moments in, a particular nation's cinematic culture. Topics might include Quebecois cinema, current British cinema, German cinema Between the Wars, Canadian cinema, the History of Chinese cinema, etc.

Description:

Description:
Topics will explore the representation of gender and sexuality in cinema. Topics might include: Images of Women in the American 1940s, Lesbian Images in Current Cinema, The Queer 1950s, Comparative Images of Women in American and French Cinema, etc.

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
An assessment of the various ways in which the history of film production can be approached, including the development of filmmaking technologies, evolutions in cinematic style and narrative traditions, particularly as they relate to popular cinema, and changing industrial practices.

Prerequisite(s): Film 201.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (2-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 2-3 ((2-3))

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
An introduction to key concepts in cinematic historiography. Emphasis will be placed upon non-traditional or non-canonical films and their relationship to dominant histories of filmmaking.

Prerequisite(s): Film 201.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (2-3) or (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - (2-3)(3-0) ((2-3) or (3-0))

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
An introduction to theoretical perspectives on film before the mid twentieth century. Connects film with broader debates on aesthetics, medium specificity, genre, and realism. Includes theories developed in the first half of the 20th century related to Silent Film, Formalism, Montage, Critical Theory, and Auteur theories.	

Prerequisite(s): Film 201.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (2-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 2-3 ((2-3))

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
An introduction to theoretical perspectives on film developed since the mid-twentieth century, specifically Structuralism, Linguistics, Psycholanalysis, Feminism, Post-structuralism, Cultural Studies, Post-colonialism and Queer Theory.

Prerequisite(s): Film 201.

Notes: Credit for both Film 333 and 300 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (2-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 2-3 ((2-3))

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
An introduction to key historical and theoretical aspects of Canadian film. Topics will include the study of Canadian film auteurs, documentary and social change, feature film genres, and the role of government regulations. Explores the central themes and issues facing Canadian filmmakers and audiences.

Antirequisite(s): Credit for Film 351 and Canadian Studies 331 will not be allowed.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (2-3) or (3-0), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - (2-3)(3-0) ((2-3) or (3-0))

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
Topics will be organized around particular theorists, schools of theory, historical issues in film culture, or contemporary thought on film. Topics may include: Psychoanalysis and/as Film Theory; Kaja Silverman and Teresa de Lauretis; Modernism and Postmodernism; Feminist Film Theory; Queer Theory and Film; Postcolonial Theory and Film; Semiotics.

Prerequisite(s): Film 331 or 333.

Description:

Description:

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
This course is designed to provide students with the opportunity to combine interests in film studies research with experiential learning opportunities in the community and workplace (internships, paid employment, approved film production training or volunteer position).

Prerequisite(s):  Film 201, admission to the BA in Film Studies or the Bachelor of Film Studies and consent of the Department.

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
Topic may be historical, theoretical or analytical in emphasis.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
An exploration of the social practices (cultural tourism, tastemaking, identity formation, celebrity and star formation) and operational aspects (marketing, promotion, jurying, lobbying, audience cultivation) of film festivals. Students will be encouraged to participate in community service learning through volunteer opportunities with a particular festival. 	

Prerequisite(s): Film 321.

Subject: FILM - Film
Long Course Title: The Canadian Film Industry: National and Global Perspectives
Description:
A study of the nature of the Canadian film industry. Emphasis will be on the evolution of the Canadian motion picture industry in the twentieth century and how it is situated in contemporary popular culture. Other topics include Canada's historic relationship to Hollywood, the audience for Canadian films, the role of the state in funding, distribution and production systems, the impact of new technologies, and how the structure of Canada's film industry compares with those of other countries.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units of courses labelled Film, Communication and Media Studies, or Canadian Studies at the 300 level.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (2-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 2-3 ((2-3))

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
Explores aspects of spectatorship, audience and reception approaches as they intersect with the experience and study of cinema.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (2-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 2-3 ((2-3))

Subject: FILM - Film
Description:
Explores the genre of experimental film and video. Particular emphasis will be given to the history and evolution of works in this genre with attention to Canadian contributions and the impact of digital and new media.

Prerequisite(s): 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.
Course Attributes: Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A, Fee Rate Group(International) -A, GFC Hours (2-3), FRGD - A (Fee Rate Group(Domestic) - A), FRGI - A (Fee Rate Group(Int'l) - A), GFCH - 2-3 ((2-3))

Description:
Supervised individual study of a special topic.

Description:
Selected topic in film studies suitable for advanced studies in the degree. Topic may be historical, theoretical or analytical in emphasis.
